definition[0]: the ability and right to decide exactly what should be done in a particular situation
example[0]: Promotions are left to the discretion of the supervisor.
example[1]: The judge exercised his discretion rightly to admit the evidence.
example[2]: The awards are made at the discretion of the committee.
example[3]: People want to have more discretion over their working hours.
example[4]: The committee has the absolute discretion to refuse applications.
definition[1]: the ability to deal with situations in a way that does not offend, upset, or embarrass people or tell any of their secrets
example[5]: British newspapers no longer feel they must treat the royal family with discretion.
definition[2]: the ability, right, or freedom that someone has to take decisions in a particular situation
example[6]: The licensee is supposed to have complete discretion over how the station is operated.
example[7]: Your overdraft may be increased at the discretion of the bank.
example[8]: The Commission has the discretion to conduct an investigation.
